teams.name: X-Men substitute teams | X-Force (X-Men Strike Team) (2007–2014)
teams.description: X-Men squad assembled and led by Cyclops (with Wolverine serving as the field leader) to take on missions which require responses too violent or controversial for the regular X-Men to deal with directly. When Cyclops disbanded X-Force, Wolverine put a new X-Force squad together without his knowledge.

teams.name: X-Men substitute teams | X-Club/Science Team (2009–2012)
teams.description: Beast gathers a scientific squad to attempt to deal with the mutant birth crisis and reverse the effects of [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]] (''Uncanny X-Men'' #507 [2009]).

teams.name: The Lights (2010–2012)
teams.description: A team of the first mutants to surface in the world since [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]], tasked with rescuing and helping any other new mutants as they appear.

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | [[X-Force|X-Force (Cable Founded)]] (1991–2001 and 2012-2015) | X-Force (original)
teams.description: The members of the ''New Mutants'' decided to change the team name to ''X-Force'' in ''New Mutants'' #100 (1991).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | [[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]] (1986–1998 and 2005–2014) | X-Factor Investigations (2005-2013)
teams.description: Although the team debuted in X-Factor, vol. 3 #1, the majority of the group (save Layla Miller and Rictor) had already joined the team.

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | [[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]] (1986–1998 and 2005–2014) | All-New X-Factor
teams.description: A new team sponsored by Serval Industries, who purchased the X-Factor name from Madrox after the conclusion of the last series.

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | [[X-Corporation]] (2001–2005) | Amsterdam
X-Men splinter teams | [[X-Corporation]] (2001–2005) | London
X-Men splinter teams | [[X-Corporation]] (2001–2005) | Melbourne
X-Men splinter teams | [[X-Corporation]] (2001–2005) | Nairobi
X-Men splinter teams | [[X-Corporation]] (2001–2005) | New York City
X-Men splinter teams | [[List of Xavier Institute students and staff|Xavier Institute Students]]
teams.description: It was stated that there were 182 [[List of Xavier Institute students and staff|Xavier Institute students]] enrolled before [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]] (2006), after which they were reduced to 26, including [[X-23]] (plus [[Kid Omega]] in Beast's lab).  Those who did not show up in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006) are most likely depowered or even dead (42 died on the bus explosion in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 [2006]).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | New X-Men (2006–2008)
teams.description: The team debuted in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006) after a last-man-standing exercise to know which students were the most worthy to be trained. [[Wallflower (comics)|Wallflower]], [[Blindfold (comics)|Blindfold]], [[Ernst (comics)|Ernst]], and [[Gentle (comics)|Gentle]] had been excused from the exercise. The students selected were to be trained as a junior team of X-Men. Disbanded as of ''X-Men,'' vol. 2 #207 (2008).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Young X-Men (2008–2009)
teams.description:
A group of former [[X-Mansion|Xavier Institute]] students originally brought together by [[Donald Pierce]], disguised as [[Cyclops (comics)|Cyclops]],
and later mentored by [[Danielle Moonstar|Dani Moonstar]] and [[Sunspot (comics)|Sunspot]] as a new, young X-Men squad.

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''[[Omega Gang]]''' ([[Quentin Quire|Kid Omega]]–led rebel squad
teams.description:
Group of students who were on the drug ''kick'' and started a riot at Xavier's, which resulted in the deaths of [[Stepford Cuckoos|Sophie Cuckoo]] and [[Dummy (comics)|Dummy]].
First appeared in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 1 #135 (2003).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''Special Class''' (Kuan-Yin Xorn's class)
teams.description: This class first appeared in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 1 #135 (2003). It turned into a new Brotherhood in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 1 #146 (2003).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''[[New Mutants#The New Mutants, vol. 2|New Mutants]]''' (Dani Moonstar's squad, 2003–2006)
teams.description: This squad was given its name in ''New X-Men: Academy X'' #2 (2004) and disbanded in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006). The squad had previously appeared without a name in ''New Mutants,'' vol. 2 #1–13 (2003–2004).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''[[Hellions (comics)#The Xavier Institute's Hellions squad|Hellions]]''' (Emma Frost's squad)
teams.description: Created in ''New X-Men: Academy X'' #2 (2004) and disbanded in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''[[Xavier Institute student body#Corsairs|Corsairs]]''' (Cyclops's squad)
teams.description: This squad was created in ''New X-Men: Academy X'' #2 (2004) and disbanded in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''Advocates''' (Rogue's squad)
teams.description:
This squad was only seen once, in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #444 (2004). It disbanded in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006). It was named in 2010. ''Official Handbook of the Marvel Universe A to Z,'' vol. 13 (2010)
Apparently no members remained powered. They possibly died in the bus explosion in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''[[Paragons (comics)|Paragons]]''' (Wolfsbane's squad, then Karma's, and finally Magma's)
teams.description:
This squad's name was seen on the field day results in ''New X-Men: Academy X'' #10 (2005).
They first appeared in ''New X-Men: Academy X'' #12 (2005) and disbanded in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''[[Alpha Squadron (comics)|Alpha Squadron]]''' (Northstar's squad and then Karma's)
teams.description:
This squad's name was seen on the field day results in ''New X-Men: Academy X'' #4 (2004).
They first appeared in ''New X-Men: Academy X'' #13 (2005) and disbanded in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''Chevaliers''' (Gambit's squad)
teams.description: This squad first appeared in ''X-Men,'' vol. 2 #171 (2005) and disbanded in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006). Named in 2010.<ref name=handbook13/>

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''Exemplars''' (Beast's squad)
teams.description: This squad was mentioned but never appeared on panel. Existence confirmed and partial roster revealed in 2010.<ref name=handbook13/> It disbanded in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''Paladins''' (Kitty Pryde's squad)
teams.description: This squad never appeared on panel. Existence confirmed and partial roster revealed in 2010.<ref name=handbook13/> It disbanded in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #23 (2006).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''Excelsiors''' (Iceman's squad)
teams.description: This squad was mentioned but never appeared on panel, and its roster was never revealed. Existence confirmed in 2010.[17] It disbanded in New X-Men, vol. 2 #23 (2006).

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Other student squads (2003–2006) | '''Lower School
teams.description: The Lower School, made up of the students who are too young to be in a squad was left in Karma's charge.

teams.name: X-Men splinter teams | Students with no squad known (2003–2006)
teams.description: Here are the students who were shown but whose squads are not known or who died or left the Institute before joining one. It is likely that some of them were members of squads whose full rosters have not yet been revealed, including the Exemplars, the Excelsiors, the Paladins, Storm's squad, and possibly the Chevaliers.

teams.name: Unofficial/Unsanctioned X-Men
teams.description: The following are teams who have used the name of X-Men without express permission of the official X-Men, sometimes opposed to the X-Men altogether, to announce and/or promote themselves to the public.

teams.name: Unofficial/Unsanctioned X-Men | [[Cerebro's X-Men]] (1998)
Unofficial/Unsanctioned X-Men | [[Great Lakes Avengers|Great Lakes X-Men]] (2005–2006)
teams.description:
Served a [[cease and desist]] for his team's use of the [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]] name, Mr. Immortal reorganized the Great Lakes Avengers into a team of unofficial X-Men.
They have since changed their name to first Great Lakes Champions and then Great Lakes Initiative.

teams.name: Unofficial/Unsanctioned X-Men | [[Dark X-Men|Norman Osborn's X-Men]] (2009–2010)
teams.description: A team of X-Men assembled by Norman Osborn during the 'Utopia' storyline as part of the overarching 'Dark Reign' event.

xmen.name: Professor X
xmen.description: Xavier founded the [[X-Men]] and was the original headmaster of [[X-Mansion|the Xavier Institute for Higher Learning]].<ref>''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #46 (2008)</ref>
xmen.powers: World's most powerful [[telepath]], capable of [[astral projection]], [[mind control]], illusion casting, memory manipulation, psychic blasts, and sensing the presence of nearby [[mutants]].
xmen.team: Original X-Men (1963-1970)

xmen.name: Cyclops (comics)|Cyclops
xmen.description: Xavier's first recruit and often the group's field leader. Former headmaster of the [[X-Mansion|Xavier Institute]], the former leader of the original [[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]],<ref>''X-Factor,'' vol. 1 #1 (1986)</ref> and the current leader of an offshoot X-Men team. He also formerly led the X-Men's [[X-Force (comics)|X-Force]] squad.<ref>''X-Force,'' vol. 3 #1 (2008)</ref> He is the ex-husband of Madelyne Pryor, the widower of Jean Grey and ex-boyfriend of Emma Frost.<ref>''[[X-Men: Legacy|New X-Men]],'' vol. 1 #156 (2004)</ref>  Declared deceased, but the circumstances surrounding his death are still unknown.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Extraordinary X-Men #1|last = Lemire|first = Jeff|publisher = Marvel Comics|year = 2015|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref>
xmen.powers: Projects a beam of ruby-colored concussive force from his eyes, which act as interdimensional [[aperture]]s between this universe and another.
xmen.team: Original X-Men (1963-1970)

xmen.name: Iceman (comics)|Iceman]]
xmen.description: Second and youngest member of the original team. Former member of the [[Champions (comics)|Champions]], the [[Defenders (comics)|Defenders]], and [[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]]. Currently a senior staff member at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].
xmen.powers: Generates freezing temperatures to create and manipulate ice. Can transform his body into ice.
xmen.team: Original X-Men (1963-1970)

xmen.name: Warren Worthington III|Angel/Archangel]]
xmen.description: Third original team member and the only one to have acted as a costumed hero before joining the X-Men. Former member of the [[Champions (comics)|Champions]], the [[Defenders (comics)|Defenders]], [[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]], and [[X-Force]].
xmen.powers: Makes use of the large, feathered wings on his back for natural flight. Also has eagle-like vision and blood with regenerative properties. Can formerly transform into a blue-skinned form with metallic, techno-organic wings, sharp metallic claws, and enhanced physical abilities.  Currently can shoot light beams from his hands.
xmen.team: Original X-Men (1963-1970)

xmen.name: Beast (comics)|Beast
xmen.description: Original team's other scientist. Former member of the [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]], the [[Defenders (comics)|Defenders]], and [[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]] and currently is an agent of [[S.W.O.R.D. (comics)|S.W.O.R.D.]] and the [[Illuminati (comics)|Illuminati]]. Former vice principal at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].  Currently the only mutant among a squad of [[Inhumans]].
xmen.powers: Has superhuman strength, speed, stamina, agility, reflexes, and durability. His former feline-like form gave him night vision, minor pheromone control, enhanced senses and claws.
xmen.team: Original X-Men (1963-1970)

xmen.name: Jean Grey|Marvel Girl/Phoenix
xmen.description: Fifth and final of the team's founding members, although she had met Xavier before the others. Left the team in X-Men vol.1 #94. Rejoins at the end of the Muir Island Saga, X-Factor vol. 1 #70.  Ex-wife of Scott Summers. She was killed by Kuan-Yin Xorn in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 1 #150 (2004) and was later resurrected by the [[Phoenix (comics)|Phoenix Force]] in ''X-Men: Phoenix – Endsong'' (2005) as '''White Phoenix of the Crown'''.
xmen.powers: Possesses [[telekinesis]] and telepathy. As the template of the Phoenix Force, she is able to generate unlimited amounts of energy, travel through time-space, and manipulate matter on a subatomic level.
xmen.team: Original X-Men (1963-1970)

xmen.name: [Mimic (comics)|Mimic
xmen.description: Blackmailed his way to the X-Men's house. He stole their powers, used them against the team, and kidnapped Jean. When he tried to enhance his powers with his dead father's machine, he lost them. Professor X then erased his memory. Former member of [[Dark X-Men|Norman Osborn's X-Men]]. Rejoined to help his friend [[Michael Pointer (comics)|Weapon Omega]].
xmen.powers: Copies other mutants' powers and abilities, sometimes permanently. Retains the original five X-Men's powers indefinitely.
xmen.team: Original X-Men 1960s recruits

xmen.name: [Kevin Sydney|Changeling
xmen.description: Member of the villainous [[Factor Three]] before he secretly joined the X-Men, known only to Professor X and Jean Grey. He impersonated Professor X at Xavier's request in ''The X-Men,'' vol. 1 #40 (1968) (behind the scenes). Given the name [[Kevin Sydney|Morph]] in several alternate dimensions.
xmen.died: Died impersonating Xavier in ''The X-Men,'' vol. 1 #42 (1968), making him the first X-Man to die.
xmen.powers: [[Shapeshifting|Shapeshifter]] able to assume other humanoid forms; a latent telepath.

xmen.name: [Polaris (comics)|Magnetrix/Polaris
xmen.joined: The X-Men,'' vol. 1 #60 (1969) as Lorna Dane
xmen.description: Polaris is Magneto's daughter. Officially recruited into the team by Professor X in 'The X-Men' Vol. 1 #65.  Active as Magnetrix in ''X-Men: The Hidden Years'' #3 (2000) and as Polaris in ''X-Men,'' vol. 1 #97 (1976). She lost her powers on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]], but they were restored technologically by [[Apocalypse (comics)|Apocalypse]]. Occasional girlfriend of Havok. Former member of the [[Acolytes (comics)|Acolytes]], the [[Muir Island]] X-Men, [[Starjammers]], and [[X-Factor Investigations]]. Currently leads a new corporate [[All-New X-Factor|X-Factor]].
xmen.powers: Generates magnetic fields to manipulate metal, induce flight, create force fields, and harness energy blasts.

xmen.name: [Havok (comics)|Havok
xmen.description: Alex is Cyclops' and Vulcan's brother.  Officially recruited into the team by Professor X in 'The X-Men' Vol. 1 #65. Occasional boyfriend of Polaris and is the former leader of [[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]] and [[Starjammers]]. He was the former leader of [[Uncanny Avengers]].
xmen.powers: Generates [[plasma (physics)|plasma]] blasts and absorbs cosmic energy.

xmen.name: [Petra (comics)|Petra
xmen.description: [Retroactive continuity|Retconned]] member. Student of [[Moira MacTaggert]] who joined the X-Men for Xavier's first, secret attempt to save the original X-Men from [[Krakoa]].
xmen.died: Killed in action in ''X-Men: Deadly Genesis'' #6 (2006) (flashback), though not before saving the lives of teammates Vulcan and Darwin.
xmen.powers: Earth manipulation; can also change the composition of raw minerals.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1970s recruits

xmen.name: [Sway (comics)|Sway
xmen.description: [[Retroactive continuity|Retconned]] member. MacTaggert student who participated in the first attempt to save the original X-Men.
xmen.died: Killed in action in ''[[X-Men: Deadly Genesis]]'' #6 (2006) (flashback).
xmen.powers: Time control, as well as a form of [[Retrocognition|retrocognitive]] projection.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1970s recruits

xmen.name: [Darwin (comics)|Darwin
xmen.description: [[Retroactive continuity|Retconned]] member. MacTaggert student who participated in the first attempt to save the original X-Men. [[Missing in action]] until brought out of [[suspended animation]] by the mutant energy released on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]]. The only member of this X-Men incarnation to later rejoin the team.
xmen.powers: Constant reactive evolution.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1970s recruits

xmen.name: Vulcan (Marvel Comics)|Vulcan
xmen.description: [[Retroactive continuity|Retconned]] member and brother of Cyclops and Havok. MacTaggert student who participated in the first attempt to save the original X-Men. [[Missing in action|MIA]] until brought out of suspended animation by the [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]] mutant energy release. Attacked the X-Men before leaving earth to attack the [[Shi'ar|Shi'ar Empire]] and eventually marrying [[Deathbird]] and becoming Shi'ar emperor.
xmen.died: Killed battling Black Bolt in ''War of Kings'' #6 (2009).
xmen.powers: Capable of manipulating different types of energy on a vast scale, including mutant energies. Can survive in the vacuum of space and can fly.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1970s recruits

xmen.name: Nightcrawler (comics)|Nightcrawler]]
xmen.description: Son of Mystique. Former leader of [[Excalibur (comics)|Excalibur]] and a former [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] priest.
xmen.powers: [[Muller's morphs#Neomorph|Neomorphic]] physiology grants him a [[prehensile tail]], blue fur, invisibility in shadows, night vision, and wall-crawling. Possesses line-of-sight [[teleportation]].

xmen.name: Wolverine (character)|Wolverine
xmen.description: Nicknamed '''Logan'''. Former member of the [[United States Armed Forces|US Army]], [[Team X (comics)|Team X]], [[Alpha Flight]], [[Department H]], Department K, the [[Defenders (comics)|Defenders]], the X-Men and the Avengers. Former Headmaster of the Jean Grey School for Higher Learning.
xmen.died: Suffocated in molten adamantium.
xmen.powers: Healing factor ([[Regeneration (biology)|regeneration of tissue]], immunity to virtually all toxins and pathogens, slowed aging process), enhanced senses, and retractable bone claws. Has the indestructible metal [[adamantium]] bonded to his skeleton, allowing enhanced physical attributes and sharp adamantium claws.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1970s recruits

xmen.name: Banshee (comics)|Banshee
xmen.description: Former agent of [[Interpol]], mind-controlled operative of [[Factor Three]], co-headmaster of [[Xavier's School for Gifted Youngsters]], and leader of [[X-Corps]]. Father of [[Siryn]]. Killed by Vulcan in ''[[X-Men: Deadly Genesis]]'' #2 (2006). Resurrected by the [[Apocalypse Twins]] as a new horseman of death.
xmen.powers: Sonic scream, flight, enhanced hearing.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1970s recruits

xmen.name: Storm (Marvel Comics)|Storm]]
xmen.description: Second field leader and longtime leader of the team. Formerly married to [[Black Panther (comics)|T'Challa, the Black Panther]], now divorced. Former member of the [[Fantastic Four]]. Current Headmistress of the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].
xmen.powers: [[Weather control|Weather manipulation]] (lightning bolts, wind, rain, etc.) and flight by 'riding' wind currents.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1970s recruits

xmen.name: Sunfire (comics)|Sunfire
xmen.description: Quit in ''X-Men,'' vol. 1 #94 (1975) after only one mission, but remained an ally for years afterward. Confirmed depowered in ''[[The New Avengers (comics)|New Avengers]]'' (2006), but regained his powers when he was transformed into [[Apocalypse (comics)|Apocalypse]]'s Horseman [[Famine (comics)|Famine]]. Body destroyed while fighting [[Kang the Conqueror|Kang]], and now exists as living cosmic fire, giving him the appearance of his AoA counterpart.
xmen.powers: Generation of nuclear fire, flight by jet propulsion, absorption of and immunity to various kinds of radiation.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1970s recruits

xmen.name: Colossus (comics)|Colossus]]
xmen.description: Brother of Magik. Longtime romantic interest of Shadowcat. Former member of the [[Acolytes (comics)|Acolytes]] and [[Excalibur (comics)|Excalibur]]. Died while releasing a cure for the [[Legacy Virus]] in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #390 (2001). Revealed in ''[[Astonishing X-Men]],'' vol. 3 #4 (2004) that Colossus was later restored to life by [[Ord (comics)|Ord]].
xmen.powers: Transforms into living organic metal form, granting superhuman strength and near-invulnerability. Can survive without oxygen or sustenance for long periods while in this form.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1970s recruits

xmen.name: Thunderbird (comics)|Thunderbird
xmen.description: His younger brother, [[Warpath (comics)|James Proudstar]], a.k.a. Warpath, is a member of the X-Men.
xmen.died: Killed while attempting to stop [[Count Nefaria]] in ''X-Men,'' vol. 1 #95 (1975).Temporarily resurrected by [[Eli Bard]] using a form of the [[Techno-organic virus|T-O Virus]].
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, speed, and durability.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1970s recruits

xmen.name: Kitty Pryde|Sprite/Ariel/Shadowcat
xmen.description: Active as Sprite in ''X-Men,'' vol. 1 #139 (1980); active as Ariel in ''[[Marvel Graphic Novel]]'' #5 (1982); active as Shadowcat in ''Kitty Pryde & Wolverine'' #5 (1985). Former member of [[Excalibur (comics)|Excalibur]]. Former Headmistress of the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]]. Currently a teacher at the New Charles Xavier School for Mutants and a member of Cyclops' renegade faction of X-Men.
xmen.powers: Can pass through solid matter ('phasing'), also allowing her to disrupt electronics and walk on air.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1980s recruits

xmen.name: Lockheed (comics)|Lockheed
xmen.description: Extraterrestrial dragon exiled on Earth. Formerly a member of Excalibur and currently an agent of [[S.W.O.R.D. (comics)|S.W.O.R.D.]] Close ally of Shadowcat. Worked with [[Lockjaw (comics)|Lockjaw]] and other non-humanoid beings to track down the [[Infinity Gems]].
xmen.powers: Flight, empathy, and fire-breathing. Able to speak several languages, including English. Has shown telepathic resistance and telepathic connection with his owner, [[Kitty Pryde|Shadowcat]].
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1980s recruits

xmen.name: Rogue (comics)|Rogue
xmen.description: Has served as a field leader. Once had the powers and memories of [[Carol Danvers|Ms. Marvel]]. Forced to absorb Sunfire's abilities permanently in ''Rogue,'' vol. 3 #11 (2005). Lost those abilities when cleared of all added personalities in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 2 #46 (2008). Former member of the [[Brotherhood of Mutants|Brotherhood of Evil Mutants]]. On-and-off girlfriend of [[Gambit (comics)|Gambit]]. Currently a senior staff member at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].
xmen.powers: Absorbs powers, memories, and personalities through skin-to-skin contact. Prolonged contact with others can cause her to permanently absorb their traits and potentially kill them.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1980s recruits

xmen.name: Rachel Summers|Phoenix/Marvel Girl
xmen.description: Daughter of Jean Grey and Cyclops from [[Days of Future Past|an alternate future]] that may never come to exist. Active as Phoenix in ''Uncanny X-Men Annual'' #9 (1985) and as Marvel Girl in ''[[Uncanny X-Men]]'' #444 (2004). Previous member of the [[Starjammers]]. Currently a senior staff member at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].
xmen.powers: Telekinesis and telepathy.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1980s recruits

xmen.name: Magneto (comics)|Magneto]]
xmen.description: The team's longtime enemy was briefly 'redeemed' and appointed leader of the X-Men and their junior team, the [[New Mutants]]; became headmaster of the [[X-Mansion|Xavier Institute]] in ''[[Uncanny X-Men]]'' #200 (1985). Lost his powers on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]], as confirmed in ''[[House of M]]'' #8 (2005), but regained them through the [[High Evolutionary]]'s experimentation.
xmen.powers: Generates and controls magnetic fields for manipulating metal, flight, [[Force shield|force fields]], electrical bolts, and [[electromagnetic radiation]].
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1980s recruits

xmen.name: Longshot
xmen.description: A warrior from the [[Mojo (comics)|Mojoverse]]; not a mutant, but a [[genetic engineering|genetically engineered]] organism. Quit in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #248 (1989). Longtime on-and-off boyfriend of Dazzler. Former member of the [[Exiles (Marvel Comics)|Exiles]] and [[X-Factor Investigations]].
xmen.powers: Incredible 'luck' through subconscious manipulation of probability fields; enhanced strength and agility, advanced healing capabilities, and [[Psychometry (paranormal)|psychometry]].
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1980s recruits

xmen.name: Psylocke]]
xmen.description: Twin sister of [[Captain Britain]], a.k.a. Brian Braddock. Has served as a field leader. Killed by [[Vargas (comics)|Vargas]] in ''[[X-Treme X-Men]]'' #2 (2001). Returned in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #455 (2005). Originally Caucasian, but the [[Hand (comics)|Hand]] switched her body with the Asian Revanche, which changed and expanded her powers. Exchanged powers with Jean Grey through unexplained means. Briefly abducted by [[Madelyne Pryor]] and brainwashed as a member of the [[Brotherhood of Mutants|Sisterhood of Mutants]]. Former member of the [[Exiles (Marvel Comics)|Exiles]].
xmen.powers: Telekinesis, telekinetic [[katana]], telepathy, psychic knife, immunity to most physical or mental alteration.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1980s recruits

xmen.name: Dazzler
xmen.description: Popular singer and public mutant. Went through the [[Siege Perilous (comics)|Siege Perilous]] when the team disbanded in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #251 (1989). Formerly a member of [[Excalibur (comics)#New Excalibur (2005)|Excalibur]]. Longtime on-and-off girlfriend of Longshot. Former member of S.H.I.E.L.D.
xmen.powers: Converts sonic energy into various forms of light, including laser-like beams, brilliant flashes, and [[Holography|holograms]].
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1980s recruits

xmen.name: Forge (comics)|Forge]]
xmen.description: Quit in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #290 (1992). Former leader of X-Factor and member of X-Force.
xmen.powers: Superhuman invention skill allows for intuitive knowledge of how to construct and understand anything of a mechanical nature; limited [[Magic (paranormal)|magical]] abilities. Right hand and leg replaced by advanced mechanical prosthetic limbs.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1980s recruits

xmen.name: Gambit (comics)|Gambit
xmen.description: Former thief who served as field leader. Infiltrated [[Apocalypse (comics)|Apocalypse]]'s Horsemen in ''X-Men,'' vol. 2 #184 and then [[Mister Sinister]]'s [[Marauders (comics)|Marauders]]. On-and-off boyfriend of Rogue. His primary weapons are cards, and his secondary weapon is his bo staff. Formerly a senior staff member at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].
xmen.powers: Charges inanimate objects with explosive kinetic energy; enhanced agility and [[Hypnosis|hypnotic]] charm.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1990s recruits

xmen.name: Jubilee (comics)|Jubilee
xmen.description: Ran away from home to live in a [[Shopping mall|mall]], where she discovered her powers. Joined the X-Men after saving Wolverine's life. Former member of [[Generation X (comics)|Generation X]] and [[X-Corps]]. After being depowered on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]],<ref>''Decimation: House of M - The Day After'' [2006]</ref> she served on [[Donyell Taylor]]'s [[New Warriors]] team with the codename Wondra and technology-based powers.  Transformed into a [[vampire (Marvel Comics)|vampire]] by Xarus, son of [[Dracula (Marvel Comics)|Dracula]]. Adoptive mother to a son, Shogo.
xmen.powers: Currently possesses the powers and abilities of an average vampire. Formerly could project and control explosive [[plasmoid]]s, and possessed superhuman strength and flight through advanced technology.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1990s recruits

xmen.name: Bishop (comics)|Bishop
xmen.description: Police officer from an alternate future. Left the X-Men to join [[Sentinel Squad O*N*E|O*N*E]]. Formerly one of [[Iron Man]]'s [[Registration acts (comics)|pro-registration]] forces guarding the [[Negative Zone]] prison. Betrayed the X-Men to kill [[Hope Summers (comics)|Hope Summers]] as he believed her to be an anti-messiah. Repented in the far future where he was stranded, before returning.
xmen.powers: Can absorb most forms of energy (light, heat, electricity, etc.) and channel it into blasts or convert it into enhanced strength. Has a [[bionic]] arm with enhanced strength, retractable pincers, and [[time travel|time-traveling]] capabilities.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1990s recruits

xmen.name: Revanche
xmen.description: Former [[assassination|assassin]] who switched bodies with Psylocke.
xmen.died: Died from the [[Legacy Virus]] in ''X-Men,'' vol. 2 #32 (1994).
xmen.powers: Telepathy, psychic blades, minor empathy.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1990s recruits

xmen.name: Cannonball (comics)|Cannonball
xmen.description: Joined X-Men in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #323 (1995). Former member and field leader of the original [[New Mutants]] and [[X-Force]]. First member of an affiliated team to graduate to permanent status with the X-Men. Former leader of his own X-Men squad, the New Mutants, and teacher and junior staff member at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]]. Current Avenger.
xmen.powers: Body expels [[thermochemistry|thermochemical]] energy to create a personal force field, which can be focused as explosive thrust for flight and kinetic blasts.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1990s recruits

xmen.name: Joseph (comics)|Joseph
xmen.description: [[Cloning|Clone]] of Magneto. Formerly deceased, sacrificing himself to fix the Earth's magnetic poles. Resurrected by [[Astra (comics)|Astra]].
xmen.powers: Generates and controls magnetic fields for manipulating metal, flight, force fields, electrical bolts, and electromagnetic radiation.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1990s recruits

xmen.name: Cecilia Reyes|Dr. Cecilia Reyes
xmen.description: Surgeon who was exposed as a mutant during [[Operation: Zero Tolerance]] and reluctantly joined the X-Men. Was imprisoned in the Neverland Concentration Camp in ''[[Weapon X]],'' vol. 2 #5 (2003). Was considered missing by both the X-Men and O*N*E, despite the liberation of the death camp, until her appearance in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #522 (2010).
xmen.powers: Generates a defensive psioplasmic bio-field, which can also be used offensively.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1990s recruits

xmen.name: Marrow (comics)|Marrow
xmen.description: Apparently left the team after losing control of her mutation during the six-month gap between ''Uncanny X-Men'' #380 (2000) and ''X-Men,'' vol. 1 #100 (2000). Depowered on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]]. Powers mysteriously returned prior to ''X-Force'', vol. 4 #1.
xmen.powers: Currently has bones sticking out of her body. Formerly able to generate weapons and armor from her skeletal structure. Also possessed a healing factor, enhanced strength and agility, and two hearts.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1990s recruits

xmen.name: Maggott
xmen.description: [[South Africa]]n mutant who met and joined the X-Men while searching for Magneto.  Was resurrected during the ''[[Necrosha]]'' storyline and has been seen amongst the crowd of mutants during Cyclops' address to the world on behalf of mutantkind.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Uncanny X-Men vol. 1 #600|last = Bendis|first = Brian|publisher = Marvel Comics|year = 2015|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref>
xmen.powers: Digestive system made up of twin maggot-like creatures, which can be released from his body to act independently and can eat through most forms of matter. Also possesses psychometric abilities.
xmen.team: Later recruits (1975–1999) | 1990s recruits

xmen.name: Neal Shaara|Thunderbird
xmen.description: First seen as an X-Men member in ''X-Men,'' vol. 2 #100 (2000). Quit in ''X-Treme X-Men'' #19. Retained his powers after [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]].
xmen.powers: Generates plasma blasts, which can also be used for flight.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Cable (comics)|Cable
xmen.description: Son of [[Cyclops (comics)|Cyclops]] and [[Madelyne Pryor]] who traveled to an alternate future as a baby and returned as an adult. Former [[New Mutants]] mentor and member of the original X-Force. Adoptive father of [[Hope Summers (comics)|Hope Summers]].
xmen.powers: Telekinesis, telepathy; techno-organic material on left side of body, along with advanced technological functions.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Danielle Moonstar|Mirage/Moonstar
xmen.description: Formerly codenamed Psyche, Mirage, and then Moonstar when active with the original [[New Mutants]] and [[X-Force]]. Active as Moonstar and sometimes Mirage<ref>''New Mutants'' #10 (2010)</ref><ref>''Uncanny X-Men'' #503 (2010)</ref> with the X-Men, including the New Mutants squad, which she later led. Confirmed depowered on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]] in ''House of M'' #8 (2005).
xmen.powers: Formerly capable of casting mental [[illusion]]s, communicating with animals, and sensing upcoming death.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Sage (comics)|Sage
xmen.description: Had been working with [[Professor X]] off-panel since before ''The X-Men,'' vol. 1 #1. Spied on the [[Hellfire Club (comics)|Hellfire Club]] for several years. Active as [[Sage (comics)|Sage]] in ''X-Men,'' vol. 2 #109. Quit in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #454. Former member of [[Excalibur (comics)|Excalibur]] and the [[Exiles (Marvel Comics)|Exiles]].
xmen.powers: Computer-like brain, telepathy; can detect mutant signatures, as well as trigger latent mutations.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Emma Frost|White Queen
xmen.description: Former headmistress of the [[Massachusetts Academy (comics)|Massachusetts Academy]], Xavier's School for Gifted Youngsters, and the [[X-Mansion|Xavier Institute]]. Former White Queen of the [[Hellfire Club (comics)|Hellfire Club]]'s Inner Circle. Ex-member of [[Dark X-Men|Norman Osborn's X-Men]], as well as his [[Cabal (comics)|Cabal]]. Ex-girlfriend of Cyclops.
xmen.powers: Telepathy; can transform into an organic diamond form.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Xorn
xmen.description: Exact nature and identity not fully known (see Xorn); considered dead in ''New X-Men,'' vol. 1 #150 (2004) but came back as  part of the [[Michael Pointer (comics)|Collective]] in ''New Avengers'' #16 (2006).
xmen.powers: Possessed a [[star]] in his head giving various powers such as healing and manipulation of electromagnetic waves and gravity.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Chamber (comics)|Chamber
xmen.description: Former member of [[Generation X (comics)|Generation X]]. Depowered on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]], as confirmed in ''Generation M'' #1 (2006); some powers restored by [[Clan Akkaba]] who revealed he is a descendant of [[Apocalypse (comics)|Apocalypse]]. Formerly a member of the [[New Warriors]] as Decibel with technology-based powers. Original mutant powers restored during the [[Age of X]] reality warp. Currently a junior staff member at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].
xmen.powers: Psionic powers, including energy blasts; minor telepathy.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Stacy X
xmen.description: Former [[prostitute]] who joined the X-Men. Quit in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #422 (2003). Depowered on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]], as confirmed in ''[[Generation M (comics)|Generation M]]'' #2 (2006). Joined the [[New Warriors]] team as Ripcord and was presumed killed in action;<ref>''New Warriors'', vol. 4 #16 (2008)</ref> however, she has since resurfaced with original powers and appearance.<ref>''Vengeance'' #1 (2011)</ref>
xmen.powers: Used technology that granted wall-crawling and enhanced jumping abilities, retractable metal coils, and flight. Original mutant powers of snake-like skin and pheromone control.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Lifeguard (comics)|Lifeguard
xmen.description: Sister of Slipstream. Half [[Shi'ar]]. Lover of [[Neal Shaara]]. Quit the X-Men in ''[[X-Treme X-Men]]'' #19 (2002). Retained her powers on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]].
xmen.powers: Instinctive adaptive powers; permanently has golden skin, wings, and claws.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Slipstream (comics)|Slipstream
xmen.description: Brother of Lifeguard. Half [[Shi'ar]]. Was a latent mutant whose powers were jump-started by Sage so he could save his sister and Gambit. Quit the X-Men in ''X-Treme X-Men'' #18 (2002). Depowered on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]].
xmen.powers: Formerly had teleportation focused through a special [[surfboard]].
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Northstar
xmen.description: First openly gay member of the X-Men. Twin brother of [[Aurora (comics)|Aurora]] and former member of [[Alpha Flight]]. Removed from active X-Men duty in ''X-Men,'' vol. 2 #157 (2004) by Cyclops. Killed by a brainwashed Wolverine in ''Wolverine,'' vol. 3 #25 (2005). [[Resurrection|Resurrected]] by [[Hydra (Marvel Comics)|HYDRA]] in ''Wolverine,'' vol. 3 #26 (2005). Later brainwashed by the [[Children of the Vault]], but restored by Rogue's X-Men team. Rejoined the X-Men in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #508 (2009).
xmen.powers: Superhuman speed, flight, and projection of brilliant flashes of light.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Husk (comics)|Husk
xmen.description: Former member of [[Generation X (comics)|Generation X]]. [[Cannonball (comics)|Cannonball]]'s sister. Formerly [[Warren Worthington III|Archangel]]'s girlfriend. Served as a junior staff member at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]] before quitting to join the Hellfire Academy, then later returning.
xmen.powers: Changes physical composition of body by shedding skin.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Juggernaut (comics)|Juggernaut
xmen.description: Professor Xavier's stepbrother; formerly a longtime villain. He's a superpowered human, not a mutant. After leaving the X-Men, was briefly a member of Excalibur.
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength and endurance, constant protective force field that grants invulnerability. Acts as an '[[irresistible force paradox|irresistible force]].' Is virtually [[Immortality|immortal]], and does not need to eat or breathe.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Xorn
xmen.description: Twin brother of Magneto imposter Kuan-Yin Xorn. Left in ''X-Men,'' vol. 2 #164 (2005). Confirmed depowered on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]] in ''[[The New Avengers (comics)|New Avengers]]'', but later shown still powered while in isolation in Tibet.
xmen.powers: Contains a [[black hole]] in his head, which gave him various powers such as energy manipulation, healing, and telepathy.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Mystique (comics)|Mystique
xmen.description: Former leader of the Brotherhood of Evil Mutants. Foster mother of Rogue and mother of Nightcrawler. Voted a probationary member in ''X-Men,'' vol. 2 #174 (2005). Former member of Rogue's squad who defected to the [[Marauders (comics)|Marauders]] whom she later betrayed as well.
xmen.powers: Shapeshifting, with her natural form having blue skin and yellow eyes. Possesses minor healing and reactive abilities and a slowed aging process.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Warpath (comics)|Warpath
xmen.description: Former member of the [[Hellions (comics)|Hellions]] (as Thunderbird), X-Force, and [[X-Corporation]]. Brother of John Proudstar, the first Thunderbird.
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, speed, stamina, agility, reflexes, durability, flight, and senses.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Lady Mastermind
xmen.description: Former ally of [[Sebastian Shaw (comics)|Sebastian Shaw]]; daughter of [[Mastermind (Jason Wyngarde)|Mastermind]] and half-sister of [[Mastermind (Martinique Jason)|Martinique Jason]] and Pixie. Former member of the X-Men who defected to the [[Marauders (comics)|Marauders]]. Former member of the Sisterhood of Mutants.
xmen.powers: Projects realistic illusions into the minds of others; minor telepathy.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Sabretooth (comics)|Sabretooth]]
xmen.description: Longtime foe of the X-Men and Wolverine. Formerly a member of the Marauders, the Brotherhood of Mutants, and Weapon X. Came to the X-Men for help against the Children of the Vault and joined the team, though against his will. Later rejoined after becoming morally inverted to a hero due to the events of [[AXIS (comics)|AXIS]].
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, enhanced senses, healing factor, and razor-sharp claws and teeth. Highly resistant to telepathic detection and control.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Karima Shapandar|Omega Sentinel
xmen.description: [[Prime Sentinel|Omega Prime Sentinel]]. Former member of the [[Excalibur (comics)|Genoshan Excalibur]],  and an Indian police force. Possessed by the [[Marauders (comics)|Marauder]] Malice and forced to betray the team, but later cured. Became possessed by Arkea, sister of villain [[John Sublime]], which, when purged, rendered her implants inert.
xmen.powers: [[Cyborg (comics)|Cyborg]], superhuman strength, speed, and durability. Has [[Electrostatic discharge|electrostatic]] poles mounted on her arms and unspecified weapons and mechanisms that retract into her body. Can fly and control and communicate with machines.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Armor (comics)|Armor
xmen.description: Member of the X-Men and a former student at the Xavier Institute. Taken off team and becomes regular student by orders of Headmaster Logan.
xmen.powers: Ability to generate psionic body armor that grants superhuman strength and durability.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Hepzibah (comics)|Hepzibah
xmen.description: Member of the extraterrestrial Mephitisoid race and former member of the [[Starjammers]] and the X-Force squad of X-Men. Joined the X-Men after losing her lover, [[Corsair (comics)|Corsair]], and being stranded on Earth.
xmen.powers: Enhanced agility, speed, and reflexes; retractable claws, superhuman senses, mind-altering pheromones, and night vision due to alien physiology (not a mutant).
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Pixie (X-Men)|Pixie
xmen.description: Formerly a member of the X-Men-In-Training squad and a student of the Xavier Institute. Recruited after assisting the X-Men in stopping an [[N'Garai]] invasion. Daughter of Mastermind and half-sister of Martinique Jason and Lady Mastermind.
xmen.powers: Flight, [[Hallucination|hallucinatory]] dust, magical soul dagger, and limited magic abilities, including teleportation.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Karma (comics)|Karma
xmen.description: Former staff member of the Xavier Institute. Original field leader of the [[New Mutants]]. Joined the X-Men when they re-formed in San Francisco. Former member of Cannonball's New Mutants squad. Formerly a junior staff member at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].  Last seen as a member of the Utopians, who are militantly protective of the abandoned mutant haven of the same name.
xmen.powers: Mental possession of others.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Sunspot (comics)|Sunspot
xmen.description: Founding member of the New Mutants and former member of the [[Fallen Angels (comics)|Fallen Angels]] and Cable's X-Force. Former Lord Imperial of the Hellfire Club's Inner Circle. Joined the X-Men when they re-formed, first serving as a mentor to the X-Men-In-Training squad and then joining the New Mutants squad. Current Avenger.
xmen.powers: Absorption of solar energy provides super strength, energy blasts, and flight.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Aurora (comics)|Aurora
xmen.description: Twin sister of [[Northstar]] and member of [[Alpha Flight]]. First joined the X-Men in San Francisco during the [[Skrull]] invasion.
xmen.powers: Superhuman speed and durability, flight, and light generation.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Magma (comics)|Magma
xmen.description: Former member of the original New Mutants and the Hellions. Although she was not a part of the X-Men at the time, she had [[X-Treme Sanctions Executive|U.N. X-Treme Sanctions Executive]] status while a school resident and teacher. Joined the X-Men when they relocated to San Francisco as part of the New Mutants squad.
xmen.powers: Geokinetic powers allow her to create earthquakes and volcanoes. Can project heat and flame and transform into living magma.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Doctor Nemesis
xmen.description: Co-creator of the [[Human Torch (android)|original Human Torch]] and 1940s masked crimefighter. Later served as Doctor Death in the [[Third Reich]]'s superhuman Battle-Axis team. Joined the X-Men and X-Club to help reverse the effects of [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]]. Also serves as the team physician with [[Kavita Rao]].
xmen.powers: Extended longevity, enhanced immune system, heightened eyesight, and so-called 'self-evolved intellect.'
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Madison Jeffries|Box
xmen.description: Former Alpha Flight, [[Zodiac (comics)|Zodiac]], and Weapon X member who joined the X-Men after the X-Club rescued him from an automated mutant death camp bunker in Canada. Also served as a member of the X-Club.
xmen.powers: Telekinetic ability to reshape metal, plastic, and glass.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Magik (comics)|Magik]]
xmen.description: Sister of Colossus and former member of the original New Mutants. Died in ''Uncanny X-Men'' #303 (1993) from the Legacy Virus. Resurrected by [[Belasco (comics)|Belasco]], minus her soul. Joined the X-Men on Cannonball's New Mutants squad, and later joined Cyclops' renegade faction.
xmen.powers: Creation of teleportation disks and spells. Wears magical armor and wields the Soulsword.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Namor|Namor the Sub-Mariner
xmen.description: Former member of [[Dark X-Men|Norman Osborn's X-Men]], as well as his [[Cabal (comics)|Cabal]]. Joined the real X-Men before working undercover on Norman Osborn's team, whom he betrayed before openly joining the X-Men on Utopia.
xmen.died: Decapitated by [[Hyperion (comics)|Hyperion]] in Squadron Supreme vol 4 #1 (2016).
xmen.powers: [[Amphibian|Amphibious]] physiology, superhuman strength, speed, agility, durability, and longevity; [[Bioelectromagnetism|bioelectrical]] powers. Telepathic control over marine life.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Domino (comics)|Domino
xmen.description: Former member of Cable's [[Six Pack (comics)|Six Pack]] and X-Force. Joined Cycops's secret X-Force strike force before joining the main X-Men during the [[Registration acts (comics)#Proposition X|Proposition X]] riots and the battle with Norman Osborn's Avengers and X-Men.
xmen.powers: Probability manipulation and good luck.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Cloak and Dagger (comics)|Cloak
xmen.description: Former member of [[Dark X-Men|Norman Osborn's X-Men]]. Joined the real X-Men when Emma Frost invited him to come to Utopia with her and Namor. Quit in ''Cloak and Dagger,'' vol. 4 #1 (2010).
xmen.powers: Teleportation, intangibility, and the ability to link to the [[Darkforce|Darkforce Dimension]]. Recently had powers altered by Mr. Negative that mimics abilities by Dagger.<ref>''Spider-Island: Cloak & Dagger'' #3</ref>
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Cloak and Dagger (comics)|Dagger
xmen.description: Former member of [[Dark X-Men|Norman Osborn's X-Men]]. Joined the real X-Men when Emma Frost invited her to come to Utopia. Quit in ''Cloak and Dagger,'' vol. 4 #1 (2010).
xmen.powers: Ability to create 'daggers' of light, purge addictions from people, and heal. Recently had powers altered by Mr. Negative that mimics abilities by Cloak.<ref>''Spider-Island: Cloak & Dagger'' #2</ref>
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Tabitha Smith|Boom-Boom
xmen.description: Former X-Factor trainee and member of the [[Fallen Angels (comics)|Fallen Angels]], New Mutants, X-Force, and [[Nextwave]]. Joined the X-Men after they re-formed in San Francisco.
xmen.powers: Creates balls of psionic energy that explode with concussive force.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Ariel (comics)|Ariel
xmen.description: Mutant member of the extraterrestrial race native to the Coconut Grove. Former member of the Fallen Angels who joined the X-Men following their relocation to San Francisco.
xmen.powers: Teleportation (up to [[Interstellar travel|interstellar]] distances) by linking physical doorways at her start and endpoints (due to her alien physiology); also possesses the mutant ability of psychic persuasion.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Danger Room|Danger
xmen.description: Formerly the X-Men's Danger Room. Mutated and developed self-awareness after being upgraded with Shi'ar technology. When she finally freed herself, she attacked the X-Men and attempted to kill Professor X. After being damaged by a Shi'ar salvage crew, she was repaired by Professor Xavier and has since reformed. Joined as the warden of Utopia.
xmen.powers: Able to create holographic projections and control other machines; enhanced strength and durability; flight, energy blasts, and detailed knowledge of the X-Men.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2000s recruits

xmen.name: Cypher (comics)|Cypher
xmen.description: Former member of the original New Mutants who was killed by the [[Ani-Mator]] in ''New Mutants,'' vol.1 #60 (1988) and then resurrected by [[Eli Bard]] using a form of the T-O Virus. Freed from Selene's control with Warlock's help and joined the X-Men as part of Cannonball's squad.
xmen.powers: Omnilingual.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Warlock (New Mutants)|Warlock
xmen.description: A mutant member of the alien [[Technarchy]] and former member of the New Mutants and Excalibur. Killed by [[Cameron Hodge]] in ''New Mutants,'' vol. 1 #90 (1990) and later resurrected by the [[Phalanx (comics)|Phalanx]]. Joined the X-Men during [[Selene (comics)|Selene]]'s attack on Utopia and joined Moonstar's New Mutants squad.
xmen.powers: Techno-organic body, shapeshifting, and infection and assimilation of living organisms through a virus he creates (all due to his alien physiology). His mutation is his ability to feel emotions.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Fantomex
xmen.description: Product of the [[Weapon Plus]] Program who joined the X-Men in their battle against Lobe and his group of [[Sublime (Marvel Comics)|John Sublime]] associates, also joined Wolverine's secret X-Force squad. Cloned into three bodies, one female, when he was resurrected after his death at the hands of the Skinless Man.
xmen.powers: Enhanced strength, speed, endurance, agility, and senses; has multiple brains, nano-active blood, and a separate, [[Symbiosis|symbiotic]] nervous system named E.V.A. (see below); skilled at marksmanship, hand-to-hand combat, acrobatics, and misdirection.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Fantomex#Powers and abilities|E.V.A.
xmen.description: Fantomex's external nervous system. She is generally shaped like a flying saucer but is able to change shape, including a humanoid form which she revealed after Fantomex's death.
xmen.powers: Flight; able to change shape and size, carry multiple passengers, and produce energy blasts; can merge with Fantomex.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: X-23]]/Wolverine
xmen.description: Wolverine's 23rd and first successful clone from a Weapon X recreation program who formerly served in the X-Men-In-Training and X-Force squads. Joined the X-Men to help locate and save Hope Summers from [[Bastion (comics)|Bastion]].
xmen.powers: Superhuman tracking skills, heightened senses, healing factor, poison and fatigue immunity, and two adamantium-laced bone claws on each arm, with another on each foot.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Hope Summers (comics)|Hope
xmen.description: The first mutant born after the events of [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]]. Raised in the future by her adoptive father Cable. Returned to the present and joined the X-Men in the battle against [[Bastion (comics)|Bastion]]'s forces.
xmen.powers: Power mimicry; power stabilization of newly emerged mutants; full extent of powers as yet unknown.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Joanna Cargill|Frenzy
xmen.description: A former member of the Acolytes and the [[Alliance of Evil]]. Formerly brainwashed by Jean Grey into joining the Genoshan Assault team, but wanted to become a hero after keeping her memories of the [[Age of X]] time warp. Currently an adjunct staff member at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, endurance, and stamina; steel-hard skin; resistance to injury and temperature extremes.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Legion (Marvel Comics)|Legion
xmen.description: Son of X-Men founder Professor X. Started [[Age of Apocalypse]]. Suffered from trauma which resulted in multiple personality disorder. Died in ''X-Men: Omega''. Found alive in ''[[New Mutants]]''.  Removed himself from existence in ''[[X-Men: Legacy]]''.
xmen.died: Removed himself from existence in ''[[X-Men: Legacy]]'', vol. 2, #24.
xmen.powers: Split personality allows for multiple powers such as telepathy, telekinesis, [[pyrokinesis]], time travel, astral projection, psychic blades, and more, with each power used independently by each individual persona. Underwent extensive mental training, allowing him access to and control of each persona and power at his will.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Nate Grey|X-Man
xmen.description: Refugee from the [[Age of Apocalypse]] reality. Saved from [[Sugar Man|Sugarman]] and the Omega Machine by Dani Moonstar's X-Men squad, which he then joined.
xmen.powers: Telepathy and telekinesis.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Warbird
xmen.description: Shi'ar warrior and former bodyguard of former Jean Grey Institute student Kid Gladiator. Remained behind as a teacher for the school.
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength and stamina. Master of hand-to-hand combat and use of bladed weapons.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Blink (comics)|Blink
xmen.description: Sacrificed herself to help save the world from the Phalanx. Resurrected and brainwashed by [[Selene (comics)|Selene]]. Purged of brainwashing by the X-Men and Dr. Strange. Eventually joins Moonstar's X-Men squad.
xmen.powers: Teleportation. Can focus powers through special crystals or form a shearing wave to slice targets to pieces.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Firestar
xmen.description: Former member of the [[New Warriors]] and the [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]]. Despite initially being turned down following her interview for a teaching position at the Jean Grey School, she joined the X-Men after the events of 'Battle of the Atom'.
xmen.powers: Converts electromagnetic wavelengths into microwave radiation emissions, which she can use to project thermo-concussive microwave blasts and intense heat and light, scramble frequencies, and fly.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: M (comics)|M]]
xmen.realName: Monet Yvette Clarisse Maria Therese St. Croix
xmen.description: Former member of [[Generation X (comics)|Generation X]] and [[X-Corporation]] and a founding member of [[X-Factor Investigations]]. Joined the X-Men after X-Factor disbanded.
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, durability, reflexes, coordination, hearing, and vision; flight and telepathy.
xmen.team: 2000s recruits | 2010s recruits

xmen.name: Phoenix Force (comics)|Phoenix Force
xmen.description: A cosmic entity who impersonated [[Jean Grey]].  First introduced in X-Men vol.1 #101 (1976), although she fights alongside the X-Men on and off for about a year of publications, she doesn't actually join the team until later.
xmen.powers: [[Reality warping]], omnipathy, omniscience, can power up selected beings.
xmen.team: Imposter

xmen.name: Dark Beast
xmen.description: Version of Beast from the [[Age of Apocalypse]] reality who briefly infiltrated the X-Men, replacing the original Beast. Former member of [[Dark X-Men|Norman Osborn's X-Men]].
xmen.died: Excessive self-experimentation left him dependent on a life support suit, which Cyclops inadvertently damaged, causing his death in ''Uncanny X-Men'' vol. 3, #22.
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, speed, stamina, agility, reflexes, and senses; ambidexterity with hands and feet; ape-like form with blue fur; experimentation on self provided some other powers.
xmen.team: Imposter

xmen.name: Unidentified Skrull
xmen.description: Alien [[Skrull]] who was placed on the X-Men by Skrull allies of Apocalypse. He genuinely believed himself to be [[Wolverine (character)|Wolverine]] and was unaware that he was an infiltrator.
xmen.died: Killed in ''Astonishing X-Men,'' vol. 2 #3 (1999).
xmen.powers: Shapeshifting, claws.
xmen.team: Imposter

xmen.name: Fred Duncan (comics)|Fred Duncan
xmen.description: FBI's federal liaison with the X-Men.
xmen.died: Died in an undisclosed, apparently mutant-related incident as reported in ''Uncanny X-Men Annual #17 (1993).
xmen.powers: None.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Candy Southern
xmen.description: Former girlfriend of Warren Worthington III and member of the [[Defenders (comics)|Defenders]] with him. First appeared in ''The X-Men,'' vol. 1 #31 (1967). Became an honorary member of the X-Men to help Cyclops and Jean Grey find Angel in the [[Savage Land]]. Killed by [[Cameron Hodge]]. Later became part of the [[Phalanx (comics)|Phalanx]] against her will before dying again.
xmen.died: Killed in ''[[Uncanny X-Men]]'' #306 (1993).
xmen.powers: Assimilation by the [[Phalanx (comics)|Phalanx]] changed her into a form composed of techno-organic material and gave her the ability to assimilate others into a hive organism.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Moira MacTaggert
xmen.description: Longtime ally of Xavier's before he created the X-Men. A [[geneticist]] who aided the team for most of its existence until her death.
xmen.died: Killed by Mystique in ''[[X-Men: Legacy|X-Men]],'' vol. 2 #108 (2000).
xmen.powers: None.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Lilandra Neramani|Majestrix Lilandra
xmen.description: Former ruler of the Shi'ar Empire. Ally of the Starjammers and X-Men. Former lover of Xavier. Deposed by Vulcan.
xmen.died: Assassinated during ''[[War of Kings]]''.
xmen.powers: Minor telepathy and enhanced strength, both of which are natural abilities exhibited by all members of her race.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Stevie Hunter
xmen.description: X-Men's trainer, former dancer.
xmen.powers: None.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Spider-Woman (Jessica Drew)|Spider-Woman
xmen.description: Ally of the X-Men against [[Caliban (comics)|Caliban]], the Brotherhood of Evil Mutants, Juggernaut, [[Black Tom Cassidy]], and [[Siryn]]. Ex-agent of [[S.H.I.E.L.D.]] and [[Hydra (Marvel Comics)|HYDRA]]. Currently an agent of [[S.W.O.R.D. (comics)|S.W.O.R.D.]] and a member of the Avengers.
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, speed, stamina, agility, reflexes, senses, and durability; pheromone generation. Ability to adhere to walls using bio-electric attraction and shoot beams of bio-electric energy from her hands. Immuned to all poisons and radiations.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Carol Danvers|Ms. Marvel
xmen.description: Between losing her powers as Ms. Marvel and gaining her powers as Binary, Carol was a resident of Xavier's school. Refused membership when Xavier also offered it to Rogue. Second-in-command of the [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]].
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, speed, and invulnerability; flight and cosmic energy manipulation.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Katie Power|Energizer
xmen.description: A founding member of [[Power Pack]]. Was made an honorary member of the X-Men after her siblings were captured by the [[Morlocks (comics)|Morlocks]] and Katie helped the X-Men capture those responsible.
xmen.powers: Received her powers from a [[Kymellian]], an alien [[species]]: absorb energy, translate matter and absorb the resulting energy, project plasma bursts from her chest. Also has a healing ability amplified by her siblings' presence.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Callisto (comics)|Callisto
xmen.description: First and former leader of the Morlocks. An ally of the X-Men, became Moira MacTaggert's bodyguard. Confirmed depowered on [[Decimation (comics)|M-Day]] in ''Decimation: House of M - The Day After'' (2006). Joined the [[X-Cell]].
xmen.powers: Formerly enhanced reflexes, senses, and coordination.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Madelyne Pryor|Goblin Queen/Red Queen
xmen.description: Stayed with the X-Men after Cyclops left her to form [[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]], until she became the Goblin Queen during ''[[Inferno (Marvel Comics)|Inferno]]''. Later returned, taking the name Red Queen. Tricked by Cyclops into moving her spirit form into a corpse she thought was Jean Grey. The body could not hold her power, and she disappeared.  Her spirit was later revived with a new body by Arkea.
xmen.powers: As a clone of Jean Grey, she possessed identical, but less-powerful, telekinetic and telepathic abilities. She has the ability to teleport and absorb psychic energy, as well as various mystical powers.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Gateway (comics)|Gateway
xmen.description: Unofficial member of the X-Men. Teleported the team where they needed to go while they were based in [[Australia]] following their 'deaths.' Great-grandfather of X-Men member Lucas Bishop. Also acted as an ally to Generation X.
killed in ''[[Uncanny X-Force]]''.
xmen.powers: Teleportation and opening of trans-spatial portals; telepathy and omniscience.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Quicksilver (comics)|Quicksilver
xmen.description: Resident of Xavier's mansion on two separate occasions: first when Magneto returned with Avalon; then later following Onslaught, when his wife and sister were believed dead. Former member of the [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]], the [[Brotherhood of Mutants|Brotherhood of Evil Mutants]], and [[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]]. Confirmed depowered in ''Decimation: House of M - The Day After'' (2006), though his powers were gradually restored by the [[Inhumans]]' [[Terrigen Mist]]s.
xmen.powers: Superhuman speed, agility, and reflexes.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Sabra (comics)|Sabra
xmen.description: Israeli mutant caught up in the events of 'Operation: Zero Tolerance' and fought alongside [[Iceman (comics)|Iceman]], [[Cecilia Reyes|Dr. Cecilia Reyes]] and [[Marrow (comics)|Marrow]] to free the X-Men from Bastion. Former member of the X-Corporation's Paris branch. Also she accompanies Xavier and other X-Men to Genosha after it was demolished by Sentinels. Member of the Mossad.
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, speed, agility, reflexes, durability, and the ability to heal. Anti-gravity devices with the ability to fly. Wrist gauntlets that fire plasma bursts and paralyzing quills.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Cadre K#Known Skrulls|Fiz
xmen.description: A mutant Skrull who journeyed to Earth to join the X-Men. Helped the X-Men battle [[Apocalypse]] during the ''[[Apocalypse: The Twelve]]'' storyline. Was called an honorary X-Man by the Beast. Joined Cadre K, a team of mutant Skrulls formed by Professor X.
xmen.powers: Skrull shape-shifting abilities, as well as the ability to alter his size and mass.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Red Lotus (comics)|Red Lotus
xmen.description: [[Martial arts|Martial artist]] who aided the X-Treme X-Men on more than one occasion.
xmen.powers: Superhuman agility, coordination, reflexes, and balance.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Evangeline Whedon|Vange Whedon
xmen.description: The X-Men's team lawyer.
xmen.powers: Metamorph whose transformation into an enormous red dragon can be triggered consciously or by the presence of blood.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Deadpool
xmen.description: Wade Wilson is not a mutant himself, but acquired his healing factor from Wolverine's DNA during the Weapon X process. Hired as a [[mercenary]] by the X-Men to take down Cable. Given his own costume, but also made one to resemble Marvel Girl's. Although he regarded himself as a member of X-Men, he betrayed the team for Cable. He later visited the X-Men on Utopia and became a probationary member under Domino's supervision, although this status did not last long.<ref>''Deadpool,'' vol. 4 #16–18 (2009)</ref>
xmen.powers: Superhuman healing factor, 'bodyslide' teleportation, augmented strength, speed, agility, endurance, reflexes, (cursed) immortality, extreme [[marksman]]ship and [[swordsmanship]].
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Pulse (X-Men)|Pulse
xmen.description: Partnered with Mystique when she joined the X-Men as a potential love interest for Rogue.
xmen.powers: Emits a pulsing energy that disables mutant powers and certain electronic devices.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Abigail Brand|Agent Brand
xmen.description: Head of S.W.O.R.D., an agency responsible for defending the Earth from extraterrestrial threats. Beast's girlfriend. Half alien/half mutant lineage.
xmen.powers: Ability to coat her hands in  blue flames; can communicate in different alien languages humans are unable to pronounce.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Korvus (comics)|Korvus
xmen.description: Stayed with the X-Men during their space mission to find Vulcan and defeat [[D'Ken]]. It is unknown if he became a member, but he helped fight against the [[Shi'ar]]. Current member of the [[Starjammers]].
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, speed, stamina, agility, reflexes, and durability. While wielding the [[Phoenix Force (comics)|Phoenix Blade]], he possessed the ability to fly and shoot energy blasts.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Diamond Lil (comics)|Diamond Lil
xmen.description: Former Alpha Flight member and wife of Madison Jeffries who resided on Utopia with the X-Men and assisted the team during Selene's attack on the island.
xmen.died: Killed by [[Lois London|Mortis]] in ''X-Force,'' vol. 3 #23 during Selene's attack on Utopia.
xmen.powers: Superhuman physical resistance.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Toad (comics)|Toad
xmen.description: Former member of Magneto's Brotherhood of Evil Mutants. Former janitor at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].
xmen.powers: Superhuman physical strength, prehensile tongue, and leaping.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Doop (comics)|Doop
xmen.description: Previous [[X-Statix]] member. Current adjunct staff member at the [[Jean Grey School for Higher Learning]].
xmen.powers: Levitation, accelerated healing factor, superhuman strength, extra-dimensional void within body that can store objects and people.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: Kymera
xmen.description: Future daughter of Storm who stayed in the present Jean Grey School to hunt the time displaced future Brotherhood members from her era.
xmen.powers: Unknown.
xmen.team: Allies and honorary members

xmen.name: ForgetMeNot
xmen.description: Supposed member who has been helping the team for years, but was never remembered by his teammates because of his powers. He was shot and presumably killed by Fantomex in ''X-Force'', vol 4 #10; issue #13 revealed that the real MeMe managed to save his life.
xmen.powers: Abilities cause him to be completely forgotten by anyone who has seen him as soon as they look away.

xmen.name: Spider-Man
xmen.description: Former member of the [[Fantastic Four|New Fantastic Four]], [[Heroes for Hire]] and [[Future Foundation]] and a founding member of the [[The New Avengers (comics)|New Avengers]]. Current membership in the [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]]. Joined the Jean Grey School for Higher Learning as the new guidance counselor.
xmen.powers: Superhuman strength, speed, agility, stamina, reflexes, and endurance.
